race.name: Natchez Trace Gran Fondo
race.tagline: Tennessee Natchez Trace Parkway cycling in Nashville.

terrain.surface: Mixed paved parkway and gravel roads through Natchez Trace. Moderate elevation with scenic parkway.

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Regional TN event. Nashville access and organization are good but mixed surfaces and regional field.

biased_opinion.summary: Natchez Trace Gran Fondo is a regional cycling event in Nashville, Tennessee—Natchez Trace Parkway with mixed surfaces and moderate elevation. Nashville provides excellent access and the organization is good. However, the mixed-surface format and regional field keep it in Tier 3. Spring/fall weather adds variability.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: A solid regional Tennessee cycling event with Natchez Trace Parkway. Worth it for Tennessee cyclists seeking a scenic event. Not a destination race for out-of-state travelers.

final_verdict.one_liner: Tennessee Natchez Trace Parkway cycling in Nashville.
final_verdict.should_you_race: If you're in Tennessee and want a scenic parkway event—yes, it's solid. If you want pure gravel or pro field depth—look elsewhere.
final_verdict.alternatives: For better TN events: other TN gravel races. For similar parkway events: other scenic cycling events.

logistics.food: Nashville has full dining options. Stock nutrition.
logistics.official_site: Check Natchez Trace Gran Fondo website

course_description.character: Natchez Trace Parkway mixed surfaces with moderate rolling.
course_description.signature_challenge: Natchez Trace Parkway rolling in central Tennessee.

non_negotiables.why: Natchez Trace rolling requires sustained effort.
TN spring/fall means heat is possible.

marketplace_variables.race_hook: Tennessee Natchez Trace Parkway cycling in Nashville.

logistics.explanation: Pete Dusel confirms "The route was simple, except for a few miles for the start/finish and controls, follow the Natchez Trace Parkway." Nashville provides established infrastructure with 1100-rider capacity events and pre-race mixers at Gran Fondo Cycles plus organized dinners at Finezza Italian Bistro.

length.explanation: The 65-mile distance sits between typical century training and ultra-endurance demands. pwandoff completed "my first century this year with roughly 4,600 ft climb with a majority between 40 - 80 miles" and found the experience manageable enough to plan "two in 2019." Similar distance to Crusher in the Tushar.

technicality.explanation: Pete Dusel describes the Natchez Trace as having "No stop signs, and except for a few tiny roads in Mississippi, no cross roads at grade. They're all handled with overpasses." Surface quality is pristine: "Not a pot hole the entire length we rode and, in general, the pavement in excellent condition." Less technical than The Mid South.

elevation.explanation: Pete Dusel characterizes the terrain as "Not terribly hilly, but generally rolling enough to keep it interesting." The 3,500-foot gain over 65 miles creates consistent undulation without major climbs, described as suitable for tandem riding by experienced distance cyclists. Less climbing than The Mid South.

climate.explanation: Tennessee weather remains unpredictable, but the Trace offers seasonal advantages. Winter riding benefits from ridge placement - "good in the winter cause there is very little shade and most of it is on a ridge which makes it warmer" compared to valley roads that "can be brutal." More weather exposure than Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

altitude.explanation: The Trace runs mostly on ridges rather than valley floors, but Nashville sits around 500 feet above sea level. The route "starts to get flatter" heading south, meaning minimal altitude impact on performance. No acclimatization needed. Lower altitude than Gravel Worlds — no thin-air concerns.

adventure.explanation: Hammydad notes "The Trace is probably good for riding in the aerobars" - hardly adventure cycling terrain. The monotonous "50' of grass on both sides then trees" pattern offers historical significance over wilderness exploration. Educational adventure rather than backcountry challenge.

prestige.explanation: The Gran Fondo bike shop connection reveals mixed community standing - described as "Snobbish roadie shop but they did solid work" and "A little pricey." Paulo_Sousa clarifies his shop review "was not negative... and it was quite accurate," suggesting measured local reputation.

race_quality.explanation: Organization includes structured pre-ride events with "Evening before mixer at Gran Fondo Cycles / Night before dinner at Finezza Italian Bistro." The 1100-rider capacity and established support network demonstrate proven event management capabilities.

experience.explanation: The Natchez Trace offers controlled access roads without commercial chaos, letting riders focus on the historical route. However, the "trainer"-like repetitive terrain of rolling hills through identical tree corridors limits scenic variety compared to more dramatic cycling destinations.

community.explanation: Active cycling community discusses the area with specific route knowledge - hammydad recommends "backroads surrounding the Trace (particularly Natchez Trace Rd and Liepers Creek Rd)" with detailed connector information. Local shops survive despite premium pricing, indicating dedicated cyclist base.

field_depth.explanation: The aerobars-friendly terrain attracts time trial and triathlon training rather than technical gravel racing talent. Nashville area cycling community exists but focuses on roads like "Old Hwy 96 or Waddell Hollow" for variety rather than challenging gravel competition. Less competitive depth than Almanzo 100.

value.explanation: Registration ranges from $35 early bird to $55 late, including "Welcome Party on Friday evening, bike ride, event t-shirt, finisher medal and post-ride meal." Access to 444 miles of federally maintained parkway without commercial traffic provides premium infrastructure.

expenses.explanation: Registration runs $60-100. Nashville costs stay moderate compared to coastal markets, though local cycling services command premium pricing. The Gran Fondo shop reputation for being "the only bike shop that can survive even when they sell over retail price" suggests cyclists accept higher costs for quality service. Similar expense level to Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

primary.name: Specialized Pathfinder Pro
primary.why: Fast center, grippy edges. The modern all-rounder benchmark.

primary.name: Panaracer GravelKing SK
primary.why: Affordable all-rounder. Light knobs add grip without killing speed.

primary.name: Vittoria Terreno Mix
primary.why: Graphene versatility. Mixed-terrain grip with reasonable rolling speed.

front_rear_split.rationale: Faster front for reduced rolling resistance on straights, grippier rear for traction on loose climbs and corners

youtube_data.search_query: Natchez Trace Gran Fondo gravel race Nashville

videos.title: Century Bike Ride event kicks off through Ridgeland and Natchez Trace
videos.description:
Century Bike Ride event kicks off through Ridgeland and Natchez Trace

Subscribe to WAPT on YouTube now for more: http://bit.ly/1hYcJNa

Get more Jackson news: http://www.wapt.com
Like us:  https://www.facebook.com/16wapt

videos.title: This 450 Mile Scenic Byway is Perfect for Bike Touring-The Natchez Trace
videos.description:
The Natchez Trace is a 444 mile scenic byway from Natchez, Mississippi to Nashville, Tennessee. It's closed to commercial traffic and perfect for cycling. This is day 1 of my adventure, starting in Natchez. 

Join my Patreon: https://www.patreon.com/RyanVanDuzer
The best way to support my channel is through Patreon, we have a great community over there! You get early releases with zero ads, I host monthly ZOOM hangouts,  you have direct access to ask me anything, and you get the satisfaction of knowing that you're keeping this channel ALIVE!

If Patreon isn't your thing, but you wanna contribute, use PayPal or Venmo:
PayPal: http://bit.ly/RyanVanDuzer (choose Family and Friends to eliminate fees)
Venmo- https://account.venmo.com/u/RyanVanDuzer

SUBSCRIBE TO MY CHANNEL ►https://www.youtube.com/@duzer?sub_confirmation=1

This is the bike I ride and helped design, the Priority 600ADX: https://www.prioritybicycles.com/products/600adx and my video rundown:https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Z3mRGK5YO7Q

Here's a detailed list of all my bike and camera gear: https://www.duzertv.com/my-bikepacking-gear. 

Buy my book, 'The Long Way Home' (about my 1st adventure from Honduras to Boulder) http://www.duzerbook.com

Komoot Profile: https://www.komoot.com/user/1016981454492
Strava: https://www.strava.com/athletes/108763515

Socials:
https://www.instagram.com/duzer

to to give it a shot cuz sometimes, you
know, you see something on the map and
you ride out of your way to go there and
then it's closed or something, you know?
So, but right when I walked into the
door, they were just so incredibly warm
and friendly and let me film. You know,
not everybody's comfortable with that,
but they were like, "Yep, go right
ahead." This is the kind of place where
I would love to hang out like at night
time when everybody's on the porch
drinking beers, having fun, sharing
stories.
All right, we are back on the trace
heading north. 41 miles from Jackson.
That's where I flew in yesterday.
Ole.
Whenever I meet good people, it charges
me up. It really does. Like that just
makes me feel more connected
to this place, this community, to
humanity
at large.
And it just gives me hope for humanity.
You know, you watch the news and you see
scary things all the time and bad people
doing mean things. And then you go into
a little country store in Mississippi
and just talk to real people face to
face, human to human.
And it helps you realize there's way,
way more good people out there than bad
people.
Ole. Olay. Olay.
Check out that beautiful golden
sunlight.
It's getting lower on the horizon. It's
about 5:00 p.m. I've ridden 80 miles.
Feeling good about that. Now I'm going
to try to find a place to camp. And
there's nothing on my map for real
legitimate campsites anytime soon. So, I
might go find a place to hide in the
woods.
Okay, I've been looking left and right
for a clearing and this looks pretty
good. Looks pretty promising in here.
You know, go hide myself. It's not that
I really need to hide. I don't think
anybody would really care, but you know,
there's nice peace of mind knowing that
I'm safe and tucked in the forest.
Let's see here. There might be a flat
spot with some grass on it. Make it a
little softer. Yeah, I think I'm done
for the day. What an amazing day. Let's
get set up.
>> Just like that. Lickickety lickety. All
right, there's my setup. My quilt, my
sleeping pad, and my new pillow, which I
really love. It's mainly just a place
for me to drool on at night, but I also
like the support. And I'm not gonna put
the rainfly on because
it's still pretty hot and sticky and I
don't think it's going to rain tonight.
So, I'm gonna have a little bit of fresh
air. I love that fresh air.
I'm pretty happy with this spot. I
didn't know what I would find because
some of the road is like really dense
forest and it would be hard to find flat
ground, but then I found this spot which
is awesome. Obviously,
there's still some traffic driving by.
There's way more traffic here than I'd
seen all day long. And I think it's
because I'm close to Jackson. It's also
evening, so I'm guessing there's some
commuters on the road, so I might have
to deal with some, you know, traffic
noise.
There goes a truck.
But that's okay. You know, what an
amazing
day. you know, I didn't quite know what
I was getting myself into. You know, I'd
heard about the Notch Trace for many
years, and it's kind of a legend in the
bike touring world. And, you know, day
one definitely lived up to it. And I'd
have to say the highlight of my day, and
you probably already know it, was
meeting those wonderful people at the
country store. That just made my heart
feel good. You know, when you connect
with good humans.
So, it's like 5:45 p.m.
I'm not quite sure what to do with
myself. [laughter]
Maybe I'll just lay in my tent and look
at the trees right here. Yeah, look at
those trees.
And just reminisce about a good day. I
don't bring books on my rides. I don't
really listen to music. Sometimes I do
nighttime. Sometimes I listen to
podcasts. But I really take these trips
as a time to completely just disconnect.
Except for this camera that I'm holding
right now.
Oo, you hear that? Of course you do. The
cars have all calmed down and now it's
just the bugs singing their night song.
And I love it. It's going to be fun to
sleep to this. Today was great. You
know, it was probably the easiest 88
miles I've ever ridden. It's just nice
terrain, no big hills, no headwinds,
you know, the trees block all the the
sun for the most part. There's no
traffic lights. There's no navigation
really. You know, you just get on the
trace and you ride north. So, it was
very smooth. A very good day number one.
Uh, I'm going to sleep well tonight.
Boy, nice.
Oh, and there he is.
>> Boy, my man from around here.
>> Good to see you, brother. How are you,
man?
>> And I like that you wore your shirt so
we know where you're from.
>> Yeah. Alabama, baby.
videos.curation_reason: Recent high-quality first-person ride-along showcasing the Natchez Trace route with detailed course conditions and historical context.

videos.title: BRGGF | The Buffalo River Gravel Gran Fondo (2022 Edition)
videos.description:
BRGGF 2: The Re-Buffaloing. This is the 2nd edition of this ride, put on by Bikes Unlimited and masterminded by Jeremy Ramsey. This was an epic day on the bike - good times, good people, perfect weather, near death experiences, and of course pizza and beer. If you're in the Virginia area, put this one on your calendar for next year! 

Check out my ride on Strava: https://www.strava.com/activities/7932392293

Information on the ride: https://www.mmgendurancesports.com/buffalo-river-gran-fondo



#gravelbike #cycling #buffaloriver

videos.title: From Roubaix to Shining Roubaix
videos.description: At Gran Fondo Cycles in Nashville, Tennessee we pride ourselves in allowing a person shopping for the perfect new bike to be able to compare a number of options within a price range and know that they were able to choose the bike that was perfect for them. The breadth of the Specialized Roubaix line up is a great place to see our investment in a full inventory and what it means to a buyer. Ride the midrange frame against the SL3 - can you feel the difference? Is the extra money to go from SRAM Rival to Shimano Ultegra worth it to you? Great questions - and we can help you find YOUR answers! Come see us today.
videos.transcript:
one of the most popular bikes on the
planet is the specialized rebate at
grand fondo we stock them all and we
stock size runs on these bikes
if you're looking to get started with it
we have the apex bike at 21.99 the rival
bike the uptegra bike
we even stock the dura ace bike and the
digital ultegra bike
as you move up through the line you'll
get nicer frames lighter weight bicycles
you get a ton of value somewhere in the
mid 2 000 price range with the rebate
elite with either rival or 105 or if you
want a dream bike
durace equipped here at 53.99 or digital
tegra 53.99
you feel free to come on in take a test
ride love to see you

quotes.text: I've read that this scenic byway is safer for cyclists because it's closed to commercial traffic and cars aren't supposed to go faster than 50 miles an hour. 444 miles of continuous pavement, no traffic lights, no stop signs, just a smooth country road winding through beautiful forest, farmland, and thousands of years of history.
